questions.question_text: An architect must design a QoS model for a business-critical application that is delay-sensitive and requires high bandwidth. The company’s head office hosts the application, and DMVPN tunnels protected with IPsec provide connectivity between the head office and branches. Which solution must the architect choose?

discussion.content: Does RSVP exists on it's own? - should this not be IntServ?
isn't C the answer here? IntServ uses RSVP

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network architect is preparing a network design based on the EIGRR. Routers are connected using a cat6a cable type and the inter-router connection speed is limited to 10 Mbps due to distance. During the pilot phase, a DUAL-3-SIA error message is visible. Which action must the engineer take to create a stable design?

choices.D: Create a summary route on R2.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Because the question highlights DUAL-3 SIA errors in a pilot phase (often caused by too large a query domain, slow link speeds, or both), creating a summary route on R2 is the best practice to stabilize the EIGRP network. This approach minimizes the number of queries traversing low-bandwidth links and helps avoid “Stuck in Active” conditions.

Selected Answer: A
I will go with A

choices.C: It uses JSON encoding and is compatible with a wide variety of tools on the market.
choices.D: Telemetry obtains data by parsing the CLI output from show commands.
choices.B: It uses MIB models to structure the data that are well known in the industry.
choices.A: It uses interrupt-driven polling to pull data at regular intervals.

questions.question_text: What is an advantage of using model-driven telemetry in the network?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An architect is designing an IPv4 plan using the 172.16.0.0/16. The design must maximize the number of subnets while meeting these requirements:

• 500 hosts within the server room
• 100 hosts at the remote site
• 25 hosts at the access site

Which plan must the architect choose?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the only one that makes sense -> 23 -> 512, 25 ->128 and 27 ->32

Selected Answer: B
Option B:
Server room: 172.16.2.0/23 (provides 512 IPs — good for 500 hosts).
Remote site: 172.16.4.128/25 (provides 128 IPs — good for 100 hosts).
Access site: 172.16.5.32/27 (provides 32 IPs — good for 25 hosts).
This option meets all the requirements and is very efficient in terms of IP address allocation

Selected Answer: B
A-incorrect, remote and access overlap
B-correct, maximizes subnets available without overlap and provides each site enough hosts
C-incorrect, not enough hosts at remote site
D-incorrect, remote and access sites overlap

choices.C:
• Server room 172.16.2.0/23
• Remote site 172.16.4.64/26
• Access site 172.16.5.16/28
choices.B:
• Server room 172.16.2.0/23
• Remote site 172.16.4.128/25
• Access site 172.16.5.32/27
choices.D:
• Server room 172.16.4.0/22
• Remote site 172.16.9.0/24
• Access site 172.16.9.64/26
choices.A:
• Server room 172.16.8.0/21
• Remote site 172.16.10/23
• Access site 172.16.10.128/25

questions.question_text:
An architect must design a topology for a WAN network that satisfies these requirements:

• Devices must be able to make informed decisions.
• Suboptimal paths are allowed only in case of a failure.
• Backup paths must always be available.

Which topology must the architect select?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
D. Hub and Spoke: This topology is the least ideal because it has a single central hub to which all spokes are connected. If the hub fails, all spokes lose connectivity. While it may have a backup path in some designs, it's not as resilient as a full mesh.

Selected Answer: A
Full mesh, is the only option for backup paths must always be available
